body: You may try 1) rebase branch on current master 2) push --force
I've restarted the CI build.
I'm also testing the branch over the weekend. Thanks for the quick response!

That time the failing test was because of a 504 on a git clone. (I believe it passed the first time.) I tried git push --force but it didn't seem to kick off the CI again. I am already up-to-date on master. I'll wait until the next commit and then rebase the branch again.
All tests are green!
Actually, I think the version 0.13.0 is published with a totally incorrect code base, install 0.12.0 instead.

To kick CI, just do empty `git commit --amend` followed by `git push -f`. This will modify dates of your HEAD commit, and therefore change the commit sha, and so will be seen as new content by CI bots.

In order to reduce the pressure on this issue, I've published a snapshot of the current Apache Thrift trunk with many fixes and improvements to https://www.npmjs.com/package/@biodataanalysis/thrift-trunk

Could you please test this to see if it would suite your needs? Any feedback is more than welcome.

@dcelasun I did some tweak on the implementation and this version runs much better, and I think if you have time to take a look at the code, it's ready for review :)

I didn't mark it as ready for review because I still want to test it in our real prod first (currently it's running in our staging server). I'll mark it as "ready for review" once I'm satisfied with the prod test result. Which should happen before end of day Tuesday in the US.

I lied. I didn't really test it in our prod environment (that's too risky), but I did manage to get two staging services, one running new code and one running old code, to run side-by-side for 24+ hours. In our staging setup all staging services are behind the same load balancer pool, so they are not handling exactly the same requests, but it should still be comparable:

1. Latency wise, sometimes the new code has slightly higher latency, and sometimes the old code has slightly higher latency, but overall they are quite similar (but new code seem to be tend to be the slightly slower one more often)
2. Error rate wise, it's similar to latency that it's not consistently one is better than the other, but new code does appear to be lower more often.

So I guess the conclusion we can get from there is that the new code might make latency slightly higher, but should help client pools a bit, and overall it doesn't make things worse?

Gonna mark it as "Ready for review".

Another option we could consider is to make this feature optional, either by adding a new constructor and/or field to `TSocket`/`TSSLSocket`, or add another `TSocket` implementation (`TMonitoredSocket` maybe?)

> new code seem to be tend to be the slightly slower one more often

I think a little overhead here is acceptable.

> overall it doesn't make things worse?

Agreed and generally LGTM but this PR [breaks](https://travis-ci.org/github/apache/thrift/jobs/690199684) cross [tests](https://travis-ci.org/github/apache/thrift/jobs/690199686) against C++:

@dcelasun the breaks you linked was from travis run of a previous version. I changed the code to check `isValid` instead of `IsOpen` before every Read/Write, and fixed that issue.

In the travis run of the current version, there's only one build failures and it's related to github unavailable: https://travis-ci.org/github/apache/thrift/jobs/690775140

Sorry, my bad. I had Travis open on another tab and didn't realize it was an older build.

> Another option we could consider is to make this feature optional

I'm strongly against optional features like this, they just increase our maintenance burden. If there are any significant regressions (though I don't see how) we'll address them afterwards.

If there is nothing further to add, I'll go ahead and merge this once tests are green.
In that case let me squash the two commits. I put the fixup one separately so it's easier for you to tell what is changed :)

> Now we have to find someone that can review this monster :-) :-) :-)

Recommend to ask on the mailing list. That's really a big one.
Any news here?
Could you try a rebase/push please?
@Jens-G , done.

`+474, -265` isn't really that big for C++ (which is known to be quite verbose).

And most of this diff wouldn't exist, had the classes not been choke-full of copypaste.

The main logical change is pretty simple, and I describe it thoroughly in the commit message: the retry loop of failed `bind()` is just made to do a little bit more. Sure, there's a lot of second-order detail; but the logic of main change is very simple in fact.

Hey! I think you missed some files.

I'd fixed the same warning: https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/2151/commits/c88fe54f00aef4cd7cb024dda55c1118fb043480

My commit updates 17 files; yours only 11.

@Jens-G you mean the [`thrift-dev` mail list][1]?.. Honestly, I don't see it in a healthy state.

Look at the last month: the archive is just a dump of robotic notifications from Jira and GitHub. Among 3 pages of mails, *just 2 threads* are humans talking. That's way too low [SNR][], certainly lower than on GitHub.

So what's the point? We're already in pretty good place to discuss the patch: here, in this PR on GitHub.

[1]: http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/thrift-dev/202005.mbox/browser
[SNR]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal-to-noise_ratio

> So what's the point? 

I only made a proposal. You can do whatever you find helpful.

118 commits to merge? Are you sure you did the right thing?

> @Jens-G is it possible to recieve some reaction on pull-request?

Sorry didn't see that, so late response. We regularly look through open PRs and one of the first criterions is whether CI is "red" or "green". If it is green (i.e. all checks pass) then someone will sooner or later look at it. 

If there is no reaction on a "green" CI for say 10 days or so, you may politely ask and remind about the PR. 

If the CI is "red", then your first action should be to try to fix the issues, rebase on master if necessary, and force push to the PR branch to trigger CI again. 

Sometimes, unfortunately, you may get false negatives from CI due to various reasons, so if you are sure everything is correct, a simple rebase + force-push may be just enough in such a case.
But 118 commits to merge ... I'd say you should try a rebase first, only merging your changes, and squash them into one commit.
@Jens-G  new pull request created https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/2160

Rebased on latest master. This PR addresses a minor issue that some Linux platforms require including `<signal.h>` where others seem not to urgently require it. I've also changed the `#ifdef __linux__` to `#ifdef HAVE_SIGNAL_H` that is also used in other places across all files.

Please review.
Pushed an update, and rebased on latest master.
The build errors are now very likely unrelated. Please review and merge :-)

Hm, I am completely confused now if I should use cmake or configure && make. There seems to be a cmake file inside `test/hs`, but the instructions in the top-level README refer to make. Can anybody help me?

EDIT: Ah oops, so it is cmake && make.
Hi @phile314 ,both `cmake` and `configure && make` can work, you can choose your favorite build method.But it seems that `cmake` is gradually becoming a mainstream build method.

This does seem cleaner. I'm not a fan of relying on comments for correct behaviour but that seems like a good trade-off here.

Same thing again.
> curl: (7) Failed to connect to downloads.sourceforge.net port 443: Connection timed out

Travis is doing way more uncached `docker build`s than it should.

> Travis is doing way more uncached `docker build`s than it should.

Sorry that you are bit by this. Its a known problem, I've brought it up on the mailing list recently. Sadly, there is no solution yet. For me, sometimes 100% of builds failed, so please don't get too hung up on this. And sorry again!
With a diff that big I could have easily missed something but sometimes code needs an overhaul. Code changes looked clean to me. If CI is passing: +1

I also added more comment on `socketConn.IsOpen` to explicitly call out the side-effect (I thought I pushed that last night, but apparently I forgot to do `git commit` before `git push` so push did nothing )

In most cases there shouldn't be anything between `pushDeadline` and actual `Read`, as the whole purpose of doing `pushDeadline` is to set the deadline used by the `Read`. But I just added the comment there in case in the future someone tries to do something without realizing the side-effect. I agree that is not ideal but I don't know if there's any better solutions here.

> I agree that is not ideal but I don't know if there's any better solutions here.

I can't think of anything either. Anyway, LGTM.
